description: The Georgian National Museum is the largest museum complex in Georgia, established in 2004 by unifying 20 museums and research institutions across the country. Its core, the Simon Janashia Museum of Georgia, traces its origins to 1852 when the Caucasian Department of the Russian Imperial Geographic Society was founded. This premier cultural institution preserves and showcases Georgia's rich heritage from prehistoric times through the modern era, housing over 1.2 million artifacts that tell the story of human civilization in the Caucasus region.
highlights: Archaeological Treasury in the basement featuring spectacular pre-Christian gold, silver and precious-stone artifacts dating back to the 3rd millennium BC, including fabulously detailed gold adornments from the ancient Kingdom of Colchis
The world-famous Trialeti silver cup from the first half of the 2nd millennium BC and a stunning golden cup adorned with gems and geometric patterns
Ancient human remains from Dmanisi dating back 1.8 million years - the oldest evidence of human existence outside of Africa

Collection of 146 canvases by beloved Georgian primitivist painter Niko Pirosmanashvili, alongside works by other prominent Georgian artists including Gigo Gabashvili, Lado Gudiashvili, and Davit Kakabadze

Museum of Soviet Occupation on the top floor, offering a comprehensive and moving exhibition on Georgia's 70 years under Soviet rule, paying tribute to Georgian artists, academics, and religious figures lost during Stalin's era
Human evolution exhibits with biological classifications of great apes and archaeological evidence from different eras
Ancient wine vessels decorated with images of stems and pitchers dating back to the 6th millennium BC, reflecting Georgia's ancient winemaking heritage
Gold and silver collection from various regions including Ananuri, Tsnori, Vani, Mtskheta, Trialeti Kurgans, and other significant archaeological sites
tips: Plan for 2-3 hours to properly explore the museum's 4 floors
Start in the basement Archaeological Treasury to see the most spectacular ancient treasures first
Don't miss the top floor Soviet Occupation exhibition - it's emotionally powerful and provides crucial context for understanding modern Georgia
The museum is closed on Mondays; visit Tuesday through Sunday between 10:00 AM and 6:00 PM
Located at 3 Shota Rustaveli Avenue in central Tbilisi, easily accessible near Rustaveli Avenue

The museum building itself is architecturally significant, with the Shalva Amiranashvili Museum building being an outstanding example of early classicism designed by Italian architect Giuseppe Bernardazzi
Photography policies may vary by exhibition, so check at the entrance
vibe: A journey through time that connects ancient civilizations to modern struggles for independence. The museum balances scholarly depth with emotional resonance, from the glittering splendor of 3000-year-old Colchian gold to the sobering documentation of Soviet repression. The basement treasury feels like discovering hidden treasure, while the top floor confronts Georgia's painful 20th century with dignity and defiance. Educational yet deeply moving, this is where Georgia's national identity is both preserved and proclaimed.
